author: Terry Richard | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Portland Marathon to disrupt traffic in central Portland much of Sunday
text:
Plan for traffic routing changes, bridge closures and other transportation disruptions if your destination is central Portland on Sunday, Oct. 4, due to the 44th running of the Portland Marathon.
Participants, staff and volunteers are already on the course with the 7 a.m. start of the 26.2-mile race. The busiest location is the start/finish area, which is in the heart of downtown at Southwest Fourth Avenue and Taylor Street.
Due to the length of the course and the number of participants, which should top 10,000 in the full and half marathons, traffic issues will be felt around the city as the runners make their way from downtown through west Portland, across the Willamette River on the St. John's Bridge, then return along the east side with a river crossing on the Broadway Bridge.
Stuart Tomlinson of The Oregonian/OregonLive.com summarized the bridge disruptions with this post published Wednesday: Sunday's Portland Marathon means delays, lane closures on downtown bridges , freeway ramps.
Recommended bridges to cross the Willamette River on Sunday are Fremont, Hawthorne, Ross Island, Marquam and Steel bridges. TriMet posts its service changes for the marathon on its website.
Traffic conditions should return to near normal about 3 p.m., an hour and a half after the last finishers are directed off the roadways onto sidewalks to make their way to the finish line.
